Award.AwardTitle: CC* Network Design: Transforming Arcadia's Networking Capability, Enhancing for Innovation to Grow Research Leaders in a Technology-driven World

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
As a small private university, Arcadia's existing computing infrastructure constrains the productivity of faculty in Bioinformatics, Computer Science, Chemistry, and Physics who are conducting data-intensive research. Specifically, the current infrastructure impedes researchers' ability to efficiently and securely access, share, or analyze large-data sets with collaborators at other institutions. To address these research and education needs, a collaborative team representing key university faculty and technologists at Arcadia is creating a Science DMZ with a data transmission network capable of 10Gbps connectivity (more than 10 times faster than current speeds) to the Keystone Initiative for Network Based Education and Research's (KINBER) PennREN network.

Project's objectives are to: (1) provide high performance, secure Science DMZ network capabilities for sharing of large datasets and cloud-based education; (2) eliminate technical barriers for faculty engaged in data-intensive projects through a dedicated, friction-free path to Internet2, PennREN, and other high performance computing and data resources; (3) leverage authentication and authorization mechanisms to support our faculty through the InCommon Federation; and (4) enable future scientific possibilities and unleash innovation for students and faculty researchers.

Arcadia is currently considering to incorporate a data analytics requirement into its general curriculum and leverage the newly developed cyberinfrastructure to enable cloud-based opportunities, distance learning and researching on a global scale. This opportunity is supporting greater faculty and student analytical scholarship by forming a frictionless environment built to innovate and thrive in our technology-drive world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed Arcadia University to create a dedicated, friction-free science network for transferring big data and sharing Arcadia-generated data with collaborators and the global research community. The network is supported by a collaboration between Arcadia?s IT and computer science faculty, building a bridge for science drivers/researchers on campus from all departments to quickly onboard and be able to easily utilize the network.

Thanks to this award, we were able to significantly increase our Internet bandwidth through collaboration with KINBER that opened access to the Internet2 and PennREN research networks. The Science DMZ that was deployed as part of the grant has created a dedicated environment designed for secure large data transfer and storage, using such software as Globus. A perfSONAR node deployed in the Science DMZ facilitates network performance monitoring and ensures that we know exactly how the research traffic flows from Arcadia to the global research community.

The Data Transfer Node (DTN) deployed in the Science DMZ provides the capabilities to schedule data transfers, ensure data delivery, secure data at rest, and provide authentication/authorization mechanisms for data access. An important piece of the network design in the Science DMZ is that the research traffic flowing from the DTN to the research community reaches its destination without passing through any typical border firewalls that would slow down the data transfer process, thus guaranteeing a friction-free data delivery.

To support this grant internally moving forward, we established a science advisory committee (SAC) including Associate Provost and Deans to engage in discussions with their faculty and staff, explaining the benefits of the Science DMZ and how it can be used in different disciplines for research and education activities requiring data transfer. SAC also serves as the liaison with the Provost?s Office.

This grant was initially driven primarily by the bioinformatics, computer science, physics, and chemistry programs. However, due to the accessibility of the Science DMZ, many other researchers on campus will be able to benefit from this grant in years to come, especially the faculty and students from the College of Health Sciences and Physical Therapy department. Additionally, both data analytics minor and data science major are going to be able to take advantage of the DTN capabilities to transfer research and teaching data. These programs were built as a collaboration of multiple departments and, hence, the Science DMZ is going to have a broad impact on the Arcadia community.

With the Science DMZ, the Arcadia community can easily run experiments in the enterprise cloud, Jetstream, XSEDE, Chameleon Cloud, CloudLab, GENI, Emulab, etc., and store the data back on the DTN server. This grant also facilitates attracting researchers, who are involved in studies with large amounts of data, to collaborate and work at Arcadia. More information about the grant and how researchers at Arcadia can benefit from it can be found at https://www.arcadia.edu/science-dmz
